nit: Return
Done

I think normally we don't indicate if exception is caught or thrown  "catException.." in the method name. This method can be called "dryRun" - the other method can be merged together here.
I don't quite understand why you want to catch and return? You can just throw it.
The error message of dry run is embed in this exception. The auto fixer actually needs the exception rather than the result of dry run.
nit: The line break looks weird. I think you should not hit "new line" manually when typing otherwise after reformatting it would look weird :).
I rerun it. It seems auto format will break every 100 char
How many tables can be returned at maximum?  If there are 10k+  tables, how long does it take roughly?

Given the page structure, it can download as many as it can if we use call nextPage. Here to make it simple, I will add an constraint to allow this method to only fetch max 1000 tables. Given a Table only contains name information if not reloaded, so the traffic shouldn't be heavy.
What does it mean here? Where do we read in the credentials?

This method requires connection with BigQuery server.
Uses can call gcloud auth application-default login and the credential will stored in the default path, which will be read by this method.
However, uses can download a service account credential and put it elsewhere. If this is the case, they need to modify the test cases manually.
I will put this demonstration in the comment
It is also possible to mock the BigQuery server, but I am not sure how long it will take. I guess connecting to real BigQuery and uses the public datasets may be an convenient way to test?
dryRun_success
If you want to test different cases for the same flow, consider using parameterized test, we should avoid using dryRun1, dryRun2, dryRun3...
https://www.tutorialspoint.com/junit/junit_parameterized_test.htm
Thanks for providing this.
Its recommended to use UPPER_SNAKE_CASE for constant variable names. "TABLE_FETCH_SIZE"
Done
1000 seems a bit small.. :) Maybe you can adjust this later.

nodes.bodyText: Since the service is going to be shared, we should init the variable before all tests starts and use mock annotation.
use "@mock" instead of mock()

Here may not be a good place to use @mock. BigQuery object will be injected into the BigQueryService field, which will be shared by different tests. The BigQuery object will be only mocked once in the beginning, because it is only called by the @Before method.
Why you need to mock this simple object? you can create a default instance job instance
Same there, just use a default instance. We usually don't mock out these simple objects.
